qas.question: When was the Antarctic Conservation Act passed by the U.S.?
What type of penalty can importing plants and animals into Antarctica bring?
Over fishing of which species of fish helped promote regulations on fishing?
How many tonnes of Patagonian toothfish were illegally fished in 2000?
When did the Convention for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources  come into force?
Where was the 1987 Antarctic Conservation Act passed?

plausible_answers.text: Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources

qas.question: What year did the CMACLR come into force?
What year saw illegal fishing of toothfish measure 32,000 short tons?

context: The passing of the <b5_0>Antarctic Conservation Act<b5_0/> (<a0_0>1978<a0_0/>) <b6_0>in the U.S<b6_0/>. brought several restrictions to U.S. activity on Antarctica. The introduction of alien plants or animals can bring a <a1_0>criminal<a1_0/> penalty, as can the extraction of any indigenous species. The overfishing of <a2_0>krill<a2_0/>, which plays a large role in the Antarctic ecosystem, led officials to enact regulations on fishing. The Convention for the <b7_0>Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources<b7_0/> (CCAMLR), a treaty that came into force in <a4_0><b8_0>1980<b8_0/><a4_0/>, requires that regulations managing all Southern Ocean fisheries consider potential effects on the entire Antarctic ecosystem. Despite these new acts, unregulated and illegal fishing, particularly of Patagonian toothfish (marketed as Chilean Sea Bass in the U.S.), remains a serious problem. The illegal fishing of toothfish has been increasing, with estimates of <a3_0>32,000<a3_0/> tonnes (35,300 short tons) in <b9_0>2000<b9_0/>.
